trans-unit.source: Publish Azure Application Wizard
trans-unit.target: Publish Azure Application Wizard

trans-unit.source: Publish Azure Application Wizard
trans-unit.target: Publish Azure Application Wizard

trans-unit.source: After you develop a web application in Visual Studio, you can publish that application more easily to an Azure cloud service by using the Publish Azure Application wizard.
trans-unit.target: After you develop a web application in Visual Studio, you can publish that application more easily to an Azure cloud service by using the Publish Azure Application wizard.

trans-unit.source: The first section explains the steps that you must complete before you use the wizard, and the remaining sections explain the features of the wizard.
trans-unit.target: The first section explains the steps that you must complete before you use the wizard, and the remaining sections explain the features of the wizard.

trans-unit.source: This topic is about deploying to cloud services, not to web sites. For information about deploying to web sites, see <linkText>How to Deploy an Azure Web Site</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: This topic is about deploying to cloud services, not to web sites. For information about deploying to web sites, see <linkText>How to Deploy an Azure Web Site</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Before you can publish your web application to Azure, you need to have a Microsoft account and an Azure subscription, and you have to associate your web application with an Azure cloud service.
trans-unit.target: Before you can publish your web application to Azure, you need to have a Microsoft account and an Azure subscription, and you have to associate your web application with an Azure cloud service.

trans-unit.source: If you’ve already completed these tasks, you can skip to the next section.
trans-unit.target: If you’ve already completed these tasks, you can skip to the next section.

trans-unit.source: Get a Microsoft account and an Azure subscription.
trans-unit.target: Get a Microsoft account and an Azure subscription.

trans-unit.source: You can try a free one month free Azure subscription <linkText>here</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: You can try a free one month free Azure subscription <linkText>here</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: Create a cloud service and a storage account on Azure.
trans-unit.target: Create a cloud service and a storage account on Azure.

trans-unit.source: You can do this from Server Explorer in Visual Studio, or by using the <linkText>Azure Management portal</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: You can do this from Server Explorer in Visual Studio, or by using the <linkText>Azure Management portal</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: For more information about how to set up your Azure environment, see <linkText>Setting Up Services Required to Publish a Cloud Service from Visual Studio</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information about how to set up your Azure environment, see <linkText>Setting Up Services Required to Publish a Cloud Service from Visual Studio</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Enable your web application for Azure.
trans-unit.target: Enable your web application for Azure.

trans-unit.source: To enable your web application to be published to Azure from Visual Studio, you’ll need to associate it with an Azure cloud service project in Visual Studio.
trans-unit.target: To enable your web application to be published to Azure from Visual Studio, you’ll need to associate it with an Azure cloud service project in Visual Studio.

trans-unit.source: To create the associated cloud service project, open the shortcut menu for the project for your web application, and then choose Convert, Convert to Azure Cloud Service Project.
trans-unit.target: To create the associated cloud service project, open the shortcut menu for the project for your web application, and then choose Convert, Convert to Azure Cloud Service Project.

trans-unit.source: After the cloud service project is added to your solution, open the same shortcut menu again and then choose Publish.
trans-unit.target: After the cloud service project is added to your solution, open the same shortcut menu again and then choose Publish.

trans-unit.source: For more information about how to enable applications for Azure, see <linkText>How to: Migrate and Publish a Web Application to an Azure Cloud Service from Visual Studio</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information about how to enable applications for Azure, see <linkText>How to: Migrate and Publish a Web Application to an Azure Cloud Service from Visual Studio</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Be sure to start Visual Studio with administrator credentials (Run As Administrator).
trans-unit.target: Be sure to start Visual Studio with administrator credentials (Run As Administrator).

trans-unit.source: When you’re ready to publish your application, open the shortcut menu for the Azure cloud service project, and then choose Publish.
trans-unit.target: When you’re ready to publish your application, open the shortcut menu for the Azure cloud service project, and then choose Publish.

trans-unit.source: The following steps show the Publish Azure Application wizard.
trans-unit.target: The following steps show the Publish Azure Application wizard.

trans-unit.source: Before you use the wizard for the first time, you must sign in.
trans-unit.target: Before you use the wizard for the first time, you must sign in.

trans-unit.source: Choose the Sign In link.
trans-unit.target: Choose the Sign In link.

trans-unit.source: Sign in to the Azure portal when prompted, and provide your Azure user name and password.
trans-unit.target: Sign in to the Azure portal when prompted, and provide your Azure user name and password.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>This is one of the publishing wizard screens</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>This is one of the publishing wizard screens</linkText>

trans-unit.source: The list of subscriptions populates with the subscriptions associated with your account.
trans-unit.target: The list of subscriptions populates with the subscriptions associated with your account.

trans-unit.source: You might also see subscriptions from any subscription files that you imported previously.
trans-unit.target: You might also see subscriptions from any subscription files that you imported previously.

trans-unit.source: In the Choose your subscription list, choose the subscription to use for this deployment.
trans-unit.target: In the Choose your subscription list, choose the subscription to use for this deployment.

trans-unit.source: If you choose , the Manage Subscriptions dialog box appears, and you can choose the subscription and user account you want to use. The Accounts tab shows all of your accounts, and the Subscriptions tab shows all of the subscriptions associated with the accounts. You can also choose a region from which to use Azure resources, as well as create or import certificates for your subscription from the Azure portal. If you imported any subscriptions from a subscription file, the associated certificates will appear under the Certificates tab. When you're done, choose the Close button.
trans-unit.target: If you choose , the Manage Subscriptions dialog box appears, and you can choose the subscription and user account you want to use. The Accounts tab shows all of your accounts, and the Subscriptions tab shows all of the subscriptions associated with the accounts. You can also choose a region from which to use Azure resources, as well as create or import certificates for your subscription from the Azure portal. If you imported any subscriptions from a subscription file, the associated certificates will appear under the Certificates tab. When you're done, choose the Close button.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Manage subscriptions</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Manage subscriptions</linkText>

trans-unit.source: A subscription file can contain more than one subscription.
trans-unit.target: A subscription file can contain more than one subscription.

trans-unit.source: Choose the Next button to continue.
trans-unit.target: Choose the Next button to continue.

trans-unit.source: If there aren't any cloud services in your subscription, you need to create a cloud service in Azure to host your project.
trans-unit.target: If there aren't any cloud services in your subscription, you need to create a cloud service in Azure to host your project.

trans-unit.source: The Create Cloud Service and Storage Account dialog box appears.
trans-unit.target: The Create Cloud Service and Storage Account dialog box appears.

trans-unit.source: Specify a new name for the cloud service.
trans-unit.target: Specify a new name for the cloud service.

trans-unit.source: The name must be unique in Azure.
trans-unit.target: The name must be unique in Azure.

trans-unit.source: Then specify a region or affinity group for a data center that’s near you or most of your clients.
trans-unit.target: Then specify a region or affinity group for a data center that’s near you or most of your clients.

trans-unit.source: This name is also used for a new storage account that Azure creates for your cloud service.
trans-unit.target: This name is also used for a new storage account that Azure creates for your cloud service.

trans-unit.source: Modify any settings you want for this deployment and then publish it by choosing the Publish button (The next section provides more details about the various settings).
trans-unit.target: Modify any settings you want for this deployment and then publish it by choosing the Publish button (The next section provides more details about the various settings).

trans-unit.source: To review the settings before publishing, choose the Next button.
trans-unit.target: To review the settings before publishing, choose the Next button.

trans-unit.source: If you chose Publish in this step, you can monitor the status of this deployment in Visual Studio.
trans-unit.target: If you chose Publish in this step, you can monitor the status of this deployment in Visual Studio.

trans-unit.source: You can modify both common and advanced settings for a deployment by using the Publish Azure Application wizard.
trans-unit.target: You can modify both common and advanced settings for a deployment by using the Publish Azure Application wizard.

trans-unit.source: For example, you can choose a setting to deploy your application to a test environment before you release it.
trans-unit.target: For example, you can choose a setting to deploy your application to a test environment before you release it.

trans-unit.source: The following illustration shows the Common Settings tab for an Azure deployment.
trans-unit.target: The following illustration shows the Common Settings tab for an Azure deployment.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Common Settings</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Common Settings</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In the Cloud service list, perform one of the following sets of steps:
trans-unit.target: In the Cloud service list, perform one of the following sets of steps:

trans-unit.source: In the dropdown list box, choose an existing cloud service.
trans-unit.target: In the dropdown list box, choose an existing cloud service.

trans-unit.source: The data center location for the service appears.
trans-unit.target: The data center location for the service appears.

trans-unit.source: You should note this location and make sure that your storage account location is in the same data center.
trans-unit.target: You should note this location and make sure that your storage account location is in the same data center.

trans-unit.source: Choose Create New to create a cloud service that Azure hosts.
trans-unit.target: Choose Create New to create a cloud service that Azure hosts.

trans-unit.source: In the Create Cloud Service dialog box, provide a name for the service, and then specify a region or affinity group to specify the location of the data center that you want to host this cloud service.
trans-unit.target: In the Create Cloud Service dialog box, provide a name for the service, and then specify a region or affinity group to specify the location of the data center that you want to host this cloud service.

trans-unit.source: The name must be unique in Azure.
trans-unit.target: The name must be unique in Azure.

trans-unit.source: In the Environment list, choose either Production or Staging.
trans-unit.target: In the Environment list, choose either Production or Staging.

trans-unit.source: Choose the staging environment if you want to deploy your application to a test environment.
trans-unit.target: Choose the staging environment if you want to deploy your application to a test environment.

trans-unit.source: You can move your application to the production environment later.
trans-unit.target: You can move your application to the production environment later.

trans-unit.source: In the Build configuration list, choose either Debug or Release.
trans-unit.target: In the Build configuration list, choose either Debug or Release.

trans-unit.source: In the Service configuration list, choose either Cloud or Local.
trans-unit.target: In the Service configuration list, choose either Cloud or Local.

trans-unit.source: Select the Enable Remote Desktop for all roles check box if you want to be able to remotely connect to the service.
trans-unit.target: Select the Enable Remote Desktop for all roles check box if you want to be able to remotely connect to the service.

trans-unit.source: This option is primarily used for troubleshooting.
trans-unit.target: This option is primarily used for troubleshooting.

trans-unit.source: When you select this check box, the Remote Desktop Configuration dialog box appears.
trans-unit.target: When you select this check box, the Remote Desktop Configuration dialog box appears.

trans-unit.source: Choose the Settings link to change the configuration.
trans-unit.target: Choose the Settings link to change the configuration.

trans-unit.source: Select the Enable Web Deploy for all web roles check box to enable web deployment for the service.
trans-unit.target: Select the Enable Web Deploy for all web roles check box to enable web deployment for the service.

trans-unit.source: You must enable Remote Desktop to use this feature.
trans-unit.target: You must enable Remote Desktop to use this feature.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [<linkText>Publishing a Cloud Service using the Azure Tools</linkText><title></title>](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/ff683672.aspx).
trans-unit.target: For more information, see [<linkText>Publishing a Cloud Service using the Azure Tools</linkText><title></title>](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/ff683672.aspx).

trans-unit.source: For more information about Web Deploy, see [<linkText>Publishing a Cloud Service using the Azure Tools</linkText><title></title>](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/ff683672.aspx).
trans-unit.target: For more information about Web Deploy, see [<linkText>Publishing a Cloud Service using the Azure Tools</linkText><title></title>](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/ff683672.aspx).

trans-unit.source: Choose the Advanced Settings tab.
trans-unit.target: Choose the Advanced Settings tab.

trans-unit.source: In the Deployment label field, either accept the default name, or enter a name of your choosing.
trans-unit.target: In the Deployment label field, either accept the default name, or enter a name of your choosing.

trans-unit.source: To append the date to the deployment label, leave the check box selected.
trans-unit.target: To append the date to the deployment label, leave the check box selected.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Third screen of the Publishing Wizard</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Third screen of the Publishing Wizard</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In the Storage account list, choose the storage account to use for this deployment.
trans-unit.target: In the Storage account list, choose the storage account to use for this deployment.

trans-unit.source: Compare the locations of the data centers for your cloud service and your storage account.
trans-unit.target: Compare the locations of the data centers for your cloud service and your storage account.

trans-unit.source: Ideally, these locations should be the same.
trans-unit.target: Ideally, these locations should be the same.

trans-unit.source: The Azure storage account stores the package for the application deployment.
trans-unit.target: The Azure storage account stores the package for the application deployment.

trans-unit.source: After the application is deployed, the package is removed from the storage account.
trans-unit.target: After the application is deployed, the package is removed from the storage account.

trans-unit.source: Select the Deployment update check box if you want to deploy only updated components.
trans-unit.target: Select the Deployment update check box if you want to deploy only updated components.

trans-unit.source: This type of deployment can be faster than a full deployment.
trans-unit.target: This type of deployment can be faster than a full deployment.

trans-unit.source: Choose the Settings link to open the Deployment update settings dialog box, shown in the following illustration.
trans-unit.target: Choose the Settings link to open the Deployment update settings dialog box, shown in the following illustration.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Deployment Settings</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Deployment Settings</linkText>

trans-unit.source: You can choose either of two options for update deployment, incremental or simultaneous.
trans-unit.target: You can choose either of two options for update deployment, incremental or simultaneous.

trans-unit.source: An incremental deployment updates one deployed instance at a time, so that your application remains online and available to users.
trans-unit.target: An incremental deployment updates one deployed instance at a time, so that your application remains online and available to users.

trans-unit.source: A simultaneous deployment updates all deployed instances at once.
trans-unit.target: A simultaneous deployment updates all deployed instances at once.

trans-unit.source: Simultaneous update is faster than incremental update, but if you choose this option, your application might not be available during the update process.
trans-unit.target: Simultaneous update is faster than incremental update, but if you choose this option, your application might not be available during the update process.

trans-unit.source: You should select the check box for If deployment can't be updated, do a full deployment if you want the full deployment to take place automatically if an update deployment fails.
trans-unit.target: You should select the check box for If deployment can't be updated, do a full deployment if you want the full deployment to take place automatically if an update deployment fails.

trans-unit.source: A full deployment resets the virtual IP (VIP) address for the cloud service.
trans-unit.target: A full deployment resets the virtual IP (VIP) address for the cloud service.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <linkText>How to: Retain a Constant Virtual IP Address for a Cloud Service</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <linkText>How to: Retain a Constant Virtual IP Address for a Cloud Service</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: To debug your service, select the Enable IntelliTrace check box, or if you are deploying a Debug configuration and want to debug your cloud service in Azure, select the Enable Remote Debugger for all roles checkbox to deploy the remote debugging services.
trans-unit.target: To debug your service, select the Enable IntelliTrace check box, or if you are deploying a Debug configuration and want to debug your cloud service in Azure, select the Enable Remote Debugger for all roles checkbox to deploy the remote debugging services.

trans-unit.source: To profile the application, select the Enable profiling check box, and then choose the Settings link to display the profiling options.
trans-unit.target: To profile the application, select the Enable profiling check box, and then choose the Settings link to display the profiling options.

trans-unit.source: You must use Visual Studio Ultimate to enable either IntelliTrace or Tier Interaction Profiling (TIP), and you can't enable both at the same time.
trans-unit.target: You must use Visual Studio Ultimate to enable either IntelliTrace or Tier Interaction Profiling (TIP), and you can't enable both at the same time.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <linkText>Debugging a Published Cloud Service with IntelliTrace and Visual Studio</linkText><title></title> and <linkText>Testing the Performance of a Cloud Service</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <linkText>Debugging a Published Cloud Service with IntelliTrace and Visual Studio</linkText><title></title> and <linkText>Testing the Performance of a Cloud Service</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Choose Next to view the summary page for the application.
trans-unit.target: Choose Next to view the summary page for the application.

trans-unit.source: You can choose to create a publishing profile from the settings that you have chosen. For example, you might create one profile for a test environment and another for production. To save this profile, choose the Save icon. The wizard creates the profile and saves it in the Visual Studio project. To modify the profile name, open the Target profile list, and then choose .
trans-unit.target: You can choose to create a publishing profile from the settings that you have chosen. For example, you might create one profile for a test environment and another for production. To save this profile, choose the Save icon. The wizard creates the profile and saves it in the Visual Studio project. To modify the profile name, open the Target profile list, and then choose .

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Summary screen of the Publishing Wizard</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Summary screen of the Publishing Wizard</linkText>

trans-unit.source: The publishing profile appears in Solution Explorer in Visual Studio, and the profile settings are written to a file with an .azurePubxml extension.
trans-unit.target: The publishing profile appears in Solution Explorer in Visual Studio, and the profile settings are written to a file with an .azurePubxml extension.

trans-unit.source: Settings are saved as attributes of XML tags.
trans-unit.target: Settings are saved as attributes of XML tags.

trans-unit.source: Choose Publish to publish your application.
trans-unit.target: Choose Publish to publish your application.

trans-unit.source: You can monitor the process status in the Output window in Visual Studio.
trans-unit.target: You can monitor the process status in the Output window in Visual Studio.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Setting Up Services Required to Publish a Cloud Service from Visual Studio</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Setting Up Services Required to Publish a Cloud Service from Visual Studio</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: <linkText>How to: Migrate and Publish a Web Application to an Azure Cloud Service from Visual Studio</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>How to: Migrate and Publish a Web Application to an Azure Cloud Service from Visual Studio</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Publishing a Cloud Service using the Azure Tools</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Publishing a Cloud Service using the Azure Tools</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Debugging a Published Cloud Service with IntelliTrace and Visual Studio</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Debugging a Published Cloud Service with IntelliTrace and Visual Studio</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Testing the Performance of a Cloud Service</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Testing the Performance of a Cloud Service</linkText><title></title>
